title: Vehicle Loading: Balance Safety and Efficiency
summary: Understand weight limits, cargo security, and passenger safety so your vehicle stays stable and legal.

sections.title: Why Loading Matters
sections.body: Extra passengers or cargo change how your car accelerates, brakes, and corners. Planning your load protects your licence and keeps everyone comfortable.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Never exceed the Maximum Authorised Mass (MAM) or axle weight listed in the handbook or VIN plate.
Distribute weight evenly and secure loads so they cannot move under braking.
Adjust tyre pressures and headlamp aim if your vehicle handbook recommends it when heavily loaded.

sections.title: Managing Weight and Balance
items: Place heavy items low and central in the boot to keep the centre of gravity stable.
Split passengers across seats to avoid overloading one side of the vehicle.
Use roof racks only when necessary and keep loads as light as possible to reduce drag.

sections.title: Securing Loads
sections.body: Use luggage straps, cargo nets, or built-in fixing points. Loose items become dangerous projectiles in a collision—secure them even for short trips.

sections.title: Towing and Trailers
items: Check the towing capacity of your vehicle and ensure the trailer is roadworthy with working lights and brakes.
Distribute trailer weight with about 7–10% nose weight on the tow ball to prevent snaking.
Fit the correct mirrors when towing wider loads and drive at lower speeds.

checklist.label: I know my vehicle’s Maximum Authorised Mass and stay within it.
I secure cargo so it cannot move or fall during the journey.
I adjust tyre pressures and lights when carrying heavy loads if recommended.
I brief passengers to keep seat belts fastened and spread weight evenly.

practiceTips.label: Boot drill
practiceTips.detail: Repack your boot before a lesson. Remove unnecessary items and position heavy objects low and close to the rear seat backs.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s strap check
practiceTips.detail: Practise fastening ratchet straps on a suitcase or storage box. You’ll be faster and safer when securing real loads.

practiceTips.label: Weigh it
practiceTips.detail: Use a household scale to estimate the weight of your luggage. Knowing the numbers helps you avoid accidental overloading.

questions.prompt: Why should heavy items be placed low and central in the vehicle?

options.label: It makes them easier to reach
To maintain a low centre of gravity and keep handling predictable
options.explanation: Balanced loads reduce the risk of skidding or rollover.

options.label: So the boot looks tidy
options.explanation: A tidy boot is nice, but the goal is vehicle stability.

questions.prompt: How should you adjust your driving when towing a trailer?

options.label: Drive faster to reduce journey time
options.explanation: Higher speeds increase instability when towing.

options.label: Allow more time for acceleration, braking, and cornering
options.explanation: Trailers add weight and length, so you need larger safety margins.

options.label: Switch off your indicators to save power
options.explanation: Indicators are essential—many trailers have repeaters.

questions.prompt: What does the VIN plate provide that helps with loading?

options.label: The recommended tyre brand
options.explanation: Tyre brand advice comes from the handbook, not the VIN plate.

options.label: Maximum authorised mass and axle weight limits
options.explanation: Use these figures to avoid overloading the car or axles.

options.label: Your insurance renewal date
options.explanation: Insurance details aren’t on the VIN plate.

questions.prompt: What should you do before setting off with a heavy load on the roof rack?

options.label: Nothing—roof loads don’t affect driving
options.explanation: Roof loads change centre of gravity and increase drag.

options.label: Check the rack’s weight limit, tighten straps, and plan for reduced fuel economy
options.explanation: Securing the load and adjusting expectations keeps the journey safe.

options.label: Open the sunroof for extra ventilation
